title: Guyana - Conflict Data
org: Armed Conflict Location & Event Data Project (ACLED)

bites.title: Map of locations
bite: On 1 February 2021, in New Amsterdam, East Berbice-Corentyne, security guards who are tasked with protecting government properties protested as their salaries for December 2020 have not yet been paid. [size=no report]

On 21 January 2021, off the coast of Barima-Waini, the Venezuelan navy detained two fishing boats with 12 fishermen on board and instructed them to go to Venezuelan territory where they were arrested. This arrest comes closely after Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro vowed to 'reconquer' the disputed Essequibo territory. Days later, a third fishing vessel with 7 people on board was intercepted in similar circumstances but in Venezuelan territorial waters.

On 13 January 2021, in Lusignan, Demerara-Mahaica, five prisoners stripped and beat a fellow prisoner who was imprisoned on rape charges. The beating was filmed and the footage spread online. No fatalities. [size=5]

On 11 January 2021, in Port Kaituma, Barima-Waini, three members of the Venezuelan Sindicato Gang opened fire on police officers shortly after they had robbed a jeweller. The gang members escaped by boat to Venezuela following the shoot-out. A young boy was injured by a stray bullet. No fatalities.
On 10 December 2020, in Georgetown, Demerara-Mahaica, four men chased a man accused of theft, beat him up and then tied him to a pole. [size=4]

On 7 December 2020, in Crabwood Creek, East Berbice-Corentyne, residents gathered outside the local office of the National Democratic Council (NDC) party to demand the removal of the chairman of the NDC. The demonstrators burned tires and demanded the dismissal of the official who demonstrators claim have been inefficient during his 13 years tenure. [size=no report]

On 24 October 2020, in Zee Lust, Mahaica-Berbice, residents blocked the streets in protest over the short judicial process in the case of the brutal killing of two teenagers from the region. Police intervened and removed the blockade. [size=no report]

On 21 October 2020, in Sarah Johanna, Demerara-Mahaica, residents who were illegally occupying a land claimed by a private land developer protested after construction equipment was brought in to the area under police protection. The residents claim to have lived there for 30 years but lately the owner has been trying to evacuate them. [size=no report]
On 16 October 2020, in Anna Regina, Pomeroon-Supenaam, eight employees of the town council protested in the streets over unpaid salaries. [size=eight]

On 15 October 2020, in Success, Demerara-Mahaica, two armed men attacked a security guard and stole his weapon. The men held machetes to the man's neck and threatened him. Then they drove away on a motorbike. The guard was guarding a water pump controlled by the Guyana Sugar Company which recently flooded a piece of land to drive squatters out. The attack is likely related to a land conflict.

On 15 October 2020, in Success, Demerara-Mahaica, two armed men attacked a security guard and stole his weapon then they drove away on a motorbike. The guard was guarding a water pump controlled by the Guyana Sugar Company which recently flooded a piece of land to drive squatters out. Police chased the attackers and reportedly shot a bystander during the chase. The attack is likely connected to a conflict over land. No fatalities.

On 4 October 2020, in No. 3, Mahaica-Berbice, rioters blocked the streets with flaming debris in anger over the death of two young Afro-Guyanese men a month before. Police arrived at the scene to calm things down and to clean up the debris. [size=no report]

On 4 October 2020, in No. 5, Mahaica-Berbice, rioters blocked the streets with flaming debris in anger over the death of two young Afro-Guyanese men a month before. One demonstrator was seen attacking a passing motorcyclist. Police arrived at the scene to calm things down and to clean up the debris. [size=no report]

On 24 September 2020, in Georgetown, Demerara-Mahaica, students of two schools protested in front of the Caribbean Examinations Council over discrepancies in the grading of their final exams. Such discrepancies are noted in a number of countries where the CXC operates. Students are demanding the re-grading of their exams. [size=no report]

On 24 September 2020, in Vreed-en-Hoop, Essequibo Islands-West Demerara, nurses form the West Demerara hospital protested against their working conditions during the coronavirus crisis. They say they have been working longer shifts but do not get paid more, and that they do not get a risk allowance for their exposure to contagion during the pandemic. [size=no report]

On 23 September 2020, in Linden, Upper Takutu-Upper Essequibo, nurses protested to ask for a risk allowance as a reward for their work during the coronavirus pandemic. The protest was successful and the minister allocated $150 million allowance, recognizing the work the nurses had done. [size=no report]

On 23 September 2020, in Nigg, East Berbice-Corentyne, a handful of people protested for the second day outside the Albion Police Station and Magistrate's Court over the decision to allow the bailing out of a man who had killed a person on September 14. [size=a handful]

On 23 September 2020, near Eteringbang, Cuyuni-Mazaruni, gunmen from the Venezuelan Sindicato Gang opened fire at a joint security operation of police and military forces that was patrolling along the Cuyuni river. The state forces returned fire but nobody was injured. The presence of police and military forces was increased after Venezuelan gangsters frequently targeted gold miners on the Guyanese side of the river. No fatalities.

On 22 September 2020, in Nigg, East Berbice-Corentyne, over a dozen people protested for the second day outside the Albion Police Station and Magistrate's Court over the decision to allow the bailing out of a man who had killed a person on September 14. [size=over a dozen]
Police Forces of Guyana (2020-) Prison Guards

On 19 September 2020, in Lusignan, Demerara-Mahaica, the visit of two government ministers to a prison escalated. Prisoners who are unhappy over the amount of coronavirus infections at the prison went on hunger strike and demanded to see the ministers. When they arrived, they threw objects at the ministers, forcing them to leave. In the ensuing chaos, prisoners stormed to the gate and set fire to mattresses. Shots were fired and 2 inmates were killed, with five others being injured. 2 fatalities. [size=no report]

On 9 September 2020, in Bath Settlement, Mahaica-Berbice, rioters blocked the streets as part of a demonstration over the killing two Afro-Guyanese. A driver who wanted to get through got out his car and discharged his shotgun, after which the crowd attacked him, killing the man. 1 fatality. [size=no report]

On 9 September 2020, in Cottage, Mahaica-Berbice, protesters went out in the street after two Afro-Guyanese teenagers were found dead. No road blocks were reported, unlike on previous days, though residents reported traffic jams. [size=no report]

On 9 September 2020, in Cotton Tree, Mahaica-Berbice, protesters went out in the street after two Afro-Guyanese teenagers were found dead. No road blocks were reported, unlike on previous days. [size=no report]

On 9 September 2020, in Hopetown, Mahaica-Berbice, protesters went out in the street to protest after two Afro-Guyanese teenagers were found dead. No road blocks were reported, unlike on previous days, though residents reported traffic jams. [size=no report]

On 9 September 2020, in Mahaicony, Mahaica-Berbice, rioters took to the streets as part of a demonstration over the killing of two Afro-Guyanese. Fiery barricades were erected to block the street and at least one person passing by was attacked, beaten, robbed and had his car set on fire. [size=no report]

Around 9 September 2020 (as reported), in No 2 Village, Mahaica-Berbice, the grandson of a man suspected of killing two teenagers was killed and his body was found. The killing of the two teenagers sparked days of violent rioting in several villages in the region. 1 fatality.
On 9 September 2020, in Number 26 village, residents blocked the streets as part of a protest over the killing of two Afro-Guyanese teenagers. [size=no report]

On 9 September 2020, in No 3 Village, Mahaica-Berbice, protesters went out in the street to protest after two Afro-Guyanese teenagers were found dead. No road blocks were reported, unlike on previous days. [size=no report]

On 9 September 2020, in No 5 Village, Mahaica-Berbice, protesters went out in the street to protest after two Afro-Guyanese teenagers were found dead. No road blocks were reported, unlike on previous days, though residents reported traffic jams. [size=no report]

On 8 September 2020, in New Amsterdam, East Berbice-Corentyne, the violence from riots in the neighbouring region over the death of two Afro-Guyanese teenagers reportedly spilled over to New Amsterdam. Fires were set and a house and cars went up in flames. At least 9 racially motivated attacks on people of East Indian descent were reported in the margin of demonstrations following the killings. In addition, a barbershop and a home were burnt. No fatalities.[size=no report]

On 8 September 2020, in Belladrum, Mahaica-Berbice, residents blocked the streets for a third consecutive day with burning debris as part of a demonstration over the killing two Afro-Guyanese. Clashes between riot police and demonstrators were reported as well as rioters attacking drivers and beating them. Government officials attempted to speak with rioters but were chased away. A vehicle in the convoy of the President of Guyana who was on his way to speak with the family of the slain teenagers was attacked after which the visit was aborted. [size=no report]

On 8 September 2020, in No 40 Village, Mahaica-Berbice, residents blocked the streets with burning debris as part of a demonstration over the killing two Afro-Guyanese. Police attempted to remove debris but only led the residents to pile up more. [size=no report]

On 8 September 2020, in Burma, Mahaica-Berbice, residents blocked the streets with burning debris as part of a demonstration over the killing two Afro-Guyanese. Several incidents of drivers being verbally abused, beaten, stripped, robbed and/or having their cars damaged were reported. A man of Indian descent was driving through the riots when his car was attacked. He was dragged out of the car and then beaten and attacked with machetes. His car was set on fire. No fatalities. [size=no report]

On 8 September 2020, in Cottage, Mahaica-Berbice, residents blocked the streets with burning debris over the killing of two Afro-Guyanese teenagers from the region. A bus driver was beaten and robbed and his bus set on fire. [size=no report]

On 8 September 2020, in Edderton Village, Mahaica-Berbice, residents blocked the streets for a third consecutive day with burning debris as part of a demonstration over the killing two Afro-Guyanese. Clashes between riot police and demonstrators were reported. Furthermore several incidents of drivers being verbally abused, beaten, stripped, robbed and/or having their cars damaged were reported. [size=no report]

On 8 September 2020, in El Dorado, Mahaica-Berbice, residents blocked the streets with burning debris as part of a demonstration over the killing two Afro-Guyanese. Police attempted to remove debris but that only led the residents to pile up more. [size=no report]

On 8 September 2020, in Georgetown, Demerara-Mahaica, protesters gathered on the Cuffy Square to protest following the killing of two teenagers and stood next to a recently Black Lives Matter mural. The protesters denounced inter-ethnic tensions, and said that the killing of the two teenagers - both afro-Guyanese - was an example of ethnic based violence. [size=no report]

On 8 September 2020, in Hopetown, Mahaica-Berbice, residents blocked the streets for a third consecutive day with burning debris as part of a demonstration over the killing two Afro-Guyanese. Clashes between riot police and demonstrators were reported. Furthermore several incidents of drivers being verbally abused, beaten, stripped, robbed and/or having their cars damaged were reported. [size=no report]

On 8 September 2020, in Kingelly, Mahaica-Berbice, residents blocked the streets with burning debris as part of a demonstration over the killing two Afro-Guyanese. Police attempted to remove debris but that only led the residents to pile up more. [size=no report]

On 8 September 2020, in Lichfield, Mahaica-Berbice, residents blocked the streets with burning debris as part of a demonstration over the killing two Afro-Guyanese. Police attempted to remove debris but that only led the residents to pile up more. [size=no report]

On 8 September 2020, in Lovely Lass Village, Mahaica-Berbice, residents blocked the streets with burning debris as part of a demonstration over the killing two Afro-Guyanese. Police attempted to remove debris but that only led the residents to pile up more. [size=no report]

On 8 September 2020, in Mahaicony, Mahaica-Berbice, residents blocked the streets with burning debris as part of a demonstration over the killing two Afro-Guyanese. Some rioters attacked passers by, and a bus driver was pulled from his bus and the bus then set on fire. [size=no report]

On 8 September 2020, in No 1 Village, East Berbice-Corentyne, friends and relatives of a man who was stabbed to death blocked the road with fires and barricades as part of a demonstration over his killing. [size=no report]

On 8 September 2020, in No 22 Village, Mahaica-Berbice, residents rioted following the killing two Afro-Guyanese. One house was set on fire by rioters after a woman was seen filming them. [size=no report]

On 8 September 2020, in No 28 Village, Mahaica-Berbice, residents blocked the streets for a third consecutive day with burning debris as part of a demonstration over the killing two Afro-Guyanese. Clashes between riot police and demonstrators were reported. Furthermore several incidents of drivers being verbally abused, beaten, stripped, robbed and/or having their cars damaged were reported. [size=no report]

On 8 September 2020, in No 3 Village, Mahaica-Berbice, residents blocked the streets for a third consecutive day with burning debris as part of a demonstration over the killing two Afro-Guyanese. Clashes between riot police and demonstrators were reported. Furthermore several incidents of drivers being verbally abused, beaten, stripped, robbed and/or having their cars damaged were reported. [size=no report]

On 8 September 2020, in No 30 Village, Mahaica-Berbice, residents blocked the streets with burning debris as part of a demonstration over the killing two Afro-Guyanese. Police attempted to remove debris but that only led the residents to pile up more. [size=no report]

On 8 September 2020, in No 38 Village, East Berbice-Corentyne, rioters attacked the house of the chairman of the municipal council in the margin of demonstrations following the killing of two Afro-Guyanese teenagers. The rioters threw stones at the house and at cars parked in front. Two other people also reported that stones were thrown at their homes. A bottle of engine oil was found, which might indicate an attempt to set houses on fire. [size=no report]

On 8 September 2020, in No 40 Village, Mahaica-Berbice, residents blocked the streets with burning debris as part of a demonstration over the killing two Afro-Guyanese. Police attempted to remove debris but that only led the residents to pile up more. Furthermore several incidents of drivers being verbally abused, beaten, stripped, robbed and/or having their cars damaged were reported. [size=no report]
On 8 September 2020, in No 53 Village, East Berbice-Corentyne, residents picketed along the street as part of a protest following the killing a man who was stabbed to death. [size=no report]

On 8 September 2020, in Paradise, Mahaica-Berbice, residents blocked the streets with burning debris as part of a demonstration over the killing two Afro-Guyanese. Police attempted to remove debris but that only led the residents to pile up more. [size=no report]

On 8 September 2020, in Ross Village, Mahaica-Berbice, residents blocked the streets with burning debris as part of a demonstration over the killing two Afro-Guyanese. Police attempted to remove debris but that only led the residents to pile up more. [size=no report]

On 8 September 2020, in Zeelust Village, Mahaica-Berbice, residents blocked the streets for a third consecutive day with burning debris as part of a demonstration over the killing two Afro-Guyanese. Clashes between riot police and demonstrators were reported. Furthermore several incidents of drivers being verbally abused, beaten, stripped, robbed and/or having their cars damaged were reported. [size=no report]
On 7 September 2020, in Belladrum, Mahaica-Berbice, residents blocked the streets with burning debris as part of a demonstration over the killing two Afro-Guyanese. [size=no report]
On 7 September 2020, in Edderton Village, Mahaica-Berbice, residents blocked the streets with burning debris as part of a demonstration over the killing two Afro-Guyanese. [size=no report]

On 7 September 2020, in No One Village, East Berbice-Corentyne, residents picketed along the street over the brutal killing of two Afro-Guyanese teenagers from the region. Protesters made an attempt to block the road, but police quickly intervened and prevented the road block. [size=no report]
On 7 September 2020, in No 28 Village, Mahaica-Berbice, residents blocked the streets with burning debris as part of a demonstration over the killing two Afro-Guyanese. [size=no report]
On 7 September 2020, in No 3 Village, Mahaica-Berbice, residents took to the streets to protest following the killing of two Afro Guyanese boys. [size=no report]
On 7 September 2020, in No 53 Village, East Berbice-Corentyne, residents took to the streets to protest following the killing of two Afro-Guyanese boys. [size=no report]
On 7 September 2020, in Skeldon, East Berbice-Corentyne, residents took to the streets to protest following the killing of two Afro-Guyanaese boys. [size=no report]

On 7 September 2020, in Zeelust Village, Mahaica-Berbice, residents took to the streets and blocked traffic as part of a demonstration over the killing two Afro-Guyanese. They burnt debris, planks and other items and made a human chain to prevent the police from clearing it up. [size=no report]

On 7 September 2020, in Hopetown, Mahaica-Berbice, residents rioted over the brutal death of two Afro-Guyanese teenagers from this region. Rioters attacked, beat and robbed a taxi driver and his customers. Two other drivers also reported having been beaten by the rioters. Burning barricades on the streets were also reported. Police used tear gas and rubber bullets to disperse rioters. [size=no report]
On 6 September 2020, in Edderton Village, Mahaica-Berbice, residents took to the streets to protest following the killing of two Afro-Guyanese boys. [size=no report]

On 6 September 2020, in Zeelust Village, Mahaica-Berbice, residents took to the streets and set objects on fire as part of a demonstration over the killing two Afro-Guyanese. A pastor was beaten and robbed by the rioters. [size=no report]

On 31 August 2020, in Paradise, Mahaica-Berbice, for the second day in a row, residents burned tires and blocked roads as part of a demonstration over the arrest of the Returning Officer of the region on election fraud charges. Residents demanded the release of the Returning Officer. [size=no report]

On 31 August 2020, in El Dorado, Mahaica-Berbice, for the second day in a row, residents burned tires and blocked roads as part of a demonstration over the arrest of the Returning Officer of the region on election fraud charges. Residents demanded the release of the Returning Officer. When the Returning Officer posted bail he came to Abary where he was hoisted on the shoulders of demonstrators. [size=no report]

On 31 August 2020, in Belladrum, Mahaica-Berbice, for the second day in a row, residents burned tires and blocked roads as part of a demonstration over the arrest of the Returning Officer of the region on election fraud charges. Residents demanded the release of the Returning Officer. [size=no report]

On 31 August 2020, in Calcutta, Mahaica-Berbice, for the second day in a row, residents burned tires and blocked roads as part of demonstration over the arrest of the Returning Officer of the region on election fraud charges. Residents demanded the release of the Returning Officer. [size=no report]

On 31 August 2020, in Content, Mahaica-Berbice, for the second day in a row, residents burned tires and blocked roads as part of a demonstration over the arrest of the Returning Officer of the region on election fraud charges. Residents demanded the release of the Returning Officer. [size=no report]

On 31 August 2020, in Mahaicony, Mahaica-Berbice, for the second day in a row, residents burned tires and blocked roads as part of a demonstration over the arrest of the Returning Officer of the region on election fraud charges. Residents demanded the release of the Returning Officer. [size=no report]

On 31 August 2020, in El Dorado, Mahaica-Berbice, for the second day in a row, residents burned tires and blocked roads as part of demonstration over the arrest of the Returning Officer of the region on election fraud charges. Residents demanded the release of the Returning Officer. [size=no report]

On 30 August 2020, in Abary, Mahaica-Berbice, residents burned tires and blocked roads as part of a demonstration over the arrest of the Returning Officer of the region on election fraud charges. Residents demanded the release of the Returning Officer. [size=no report]

On 30 August 2020, in Belladrum, Mahaica-Berbice, over 200 residents burned tires and blocked roads as part of a demonstration over the arrest of the Returning Officer of the region on election fraud charges. The riots spread to neighbouring villages where residents also demanded the release of the Returning Officer. [size=over 200]

On 30 August 2020, in Calcutta, Mahaica-Berbice, residents burned tires and blocked roads as part of a demonstration over the arrest of the Returning Officer of the region on election fraud charges. Residents demanded the release of the Returning Officer. [size=no report]

On 30 August 2020, in Content, Mahaica-Berbice, residents burned tires and blocked roads as part of a demonstration over the arrest of the Returning Officer of the region on election fraud charges. Residents demanded the release of the Returning Officer. [size=no report]

On 30 August 2020, in El Dorado, Mahaica-Berbice, residents burned tires and blocked roads as part of a demonstration over the arrest of the Returning Officer of the region on election fraud charges. Residents demanded the release of the Returning Officer. Police intervened with rubber bullets and rioters threw back rocks. A demonstrator and police officer were wounded at one of the sites. [size=no report]

On 30 August 2020, in Mahaicony, Mahaica-Berbice, residents burned tires and blocked roads as part of a demonstration over the arrest of the Returning Officer of the region on election fraud charges. Residents demanded the release of the Returning Officer. [size=no report]

On 30 August 2020, in Paradise, Mahaica-Berbice, residents burned tires and blocked roads as part of a demonstration over the arrest of the Returning Officer of the region on election fraud charges. Residents demanded the release of the Returning Officer. [size=no report]

On 27 August 2020, in Paradise, Demerara-Mahaica, several people burned tires and picketed against the arrest of the Returning Officer of the region, who was arrested days before on election fraud charges. [size=several]

On 25 August 2020, in Abary, Mahaica-Berbice, the Returning Officer for Region 4 of Guyana and his assistant were arrested on election forgery charges. After the March 2020 elections, inconsistencies in vote counts were found in Region 4 which led to a recount being held and a months-long delay occurring between the vote and the announcement of results.
On 25 August 2020, in Timehri, Demerara-Mahaica, an off-duty military officer was shot and injured by two hooded gunmen in what is reported as an attempted execution. No fatalities.

On 11 August 2020, in Lusignan, Demerara-Mahaica, the house of a famous social media commentator and political analyst was the target of shootings perpetrated by unknown individuals while he was inside with friends. No fatalities.
On 8 August 2020, in Georgetown, Demerara-Mahaica, a car thief was caught red handed and beaten up by a mob of people. [size=no report]

On 2 August 2020, in Guyana, the President Irfaan Ali (PPP/C: People's Progressive Party/Civic) and Prime Minister Philips were sworn into office, five months after the election was held. During these five months a long and contested recount was held after the initial results were found to be fraudulent. Originally, the victory was attributed to the APNU-AFC party alliance but eventually given to the PP/C after vote recount.

On 26 July 2020, in Georgetown, Demerara-Mahaica, unknown individuals smashed the windows of the office of the Guyana's Human Rights Association and then ignited a tire, throwing it inside. The neighbours managed to raise the alarm and the fire was extinguished soon after.

On 25 July 2020, in Georgetown, Demerara-Mahaica, police shot and injured two unarmed men in a vehicle. Police say they opened fire in response to gun shots but investigation showed that the two men had no firearms in their possession. Officers shot at the car, then dragged the occupants out beating and kicking them, took their possessions and swabbed their hands for gunpowder residue. No fatalities.
On 22 July 2020, in Georgetown, Demerara-Mahaica, a molotov cocktail was thrown at the embassy of Suriname to Guyana. [size=no report]
Police Forces of Guyana (2015-); Military Forces of Guyana (2015-)

On 14 July 2020, in Anna Regina, Pomeroon-Supenaam, a man set fire to two government buildings: an office of the Criminal Investigations Department and another building belonging to the armed forces. [size=1]
On 8 July 2020, in Suddie, Pomeroon-Supernaam, unknown individuals attempted to set fire to the magistrates court using kerosene. [size=no report]
APNU-AFC: A Partnership for National Unity-Alliance for Change

On 6 July 2020, in New Amsterdam, East Berbice-Corentyne, a small group of protesters supporting APNU-AFC with placards protested against the Caribbean Court of Justice's involvement in perceived internal affairs ahead of a ruling regarding the recount of the general elections. The unsanctioned protest was dispersed by the police. [size=a small group]

On 6 July 2020, in Canefield, East Berbice-Corentyne, a group of over 20 people armed with improvised weapons ran amok and damaged two houses, three motorcycles and killed caged pet birds. They were looking for one of the residents, a taxi driver who was involved in an incident the day before. [size=over 20]
APNU-AFC: A Partnership for National Unity-Alliance for Change

On 6 July 2020, in Linden, Upper Takutu-Upper Essequibo, a small group of protesters supporting APNU-AFC with placards protested against the Caribbean Court of Justice's involvement in perceived internal affairs ahead of a ruling regarding the recount of the general elections. The unsanctioned protest was dispersed by the police. [size=a small group]
On 6 July 2020, in Georgetown, Demerara-Mahaica, residents torched the house of a man who was suspected of killing a neighbour after a personal dispute. [size=no report]
APNU-AFC: A Partnership for National Unity-Alliance for Change

On 6 July 2020, in Georgetown, Demerara-Mahaica, a small group of protesters supporting APNU-AFC with placards protested against the Caribbean Court of Justice's involvement in perceived internal affairs ahead of a ruling regarding the recount of the general elections. The unsanctioned protest was dispersed by the police. [size=a small group]

On 30 June 2020, in Georgetown, the car belonging to an investigative journalist was set on fire by unknown perpetrators. The car was parked at the guarded parking lot of the Ministry of Public Service. The fire department confirmed that this was a deliberate arson.
APNU-AFC: A Partnership for National Unity-Alliance for Change

On 18 June 2020, in Georgetown, Demerara-Mahaica, scores of supporters of the governing coalition ANPU-AFC marched through the streets. The protesters expressed their support for the Chief Election Officer of Guyana to submit his report on the recount to the Guyana Electoral Commission, which would verify the results of the recount of votes of the March 2 general elections. Police were present and is preparing charges against some protesters for violating the Covid-19 restrictions. [size=scores]
APNU-AFC: A Partnership for National Unity-Alliance for Change

On 18 June 2020, in New Amsterdam, East Berbice-Corentyne, a group of supporters of the governing coalition ANPU-AFC marched through the streets. The protesters expressed their support for the Chief Election Officer of Guyana to submit his report on the recount to the Guyana Electoral Commission, which would verify the results of the recount of votes of the March 2 general elections. [size=no report]
APNU-AFC: A Partnership for National Unity-Alliance for Change

On 17 June 2020, in Linden, Upper Takutu-Upper Essequibo a group of supporters of the governing coalition ANPU-AFC marched through the streets. The protesters expressed their support for the Chief Election Officer of Guyana to submit his report on the recount to the Guyana Electoral Commission, which would verify the results of the recount of votes of the March 2 general elections. [size=no report]
APNU-AFC: A Partnership for National Unity-Alliance for Change

On 9 June 2020, in Georgetown, Demerara-Mahaica, a small group of ANPU-AFC supporters with placards protested outside the Arthur Chang Convention Centre to protest the credibility of the recently held elections. Police instructed the protesters to leave after 10 minutes. [size=no report]

On 29 May 2020, in Uitvlucht, Essequibo Islands-West Demerara, a protest by workers of the Uitvlugt estate were broken up by police for the second day in a row. Police said that the protesters did not adhere to social distancing guidelines that were implemented because of coronavirus. [size=no report]

On 28 May 2020, in Uitvlugt, Essequibo Islands-West Demerara, workers of the state protested over working hours and outstanding payment for the second day in a row. This day police intervened to disperse the group of protesters, citing coronavirus rules of social distancing as the reason to end the protest. [size=no report]

On 27 May 2020, in Uitvlugt, Essequibo Islands-West Demerara, workers of the state protested protested over working hours and outstanding pay. The workers were unhappy with the arrangement over hours as a shift would end in the middle of the coronavirus curfew, due to which workers would get in trouble with police. [size=no report]

Around 24 May 2020 (as reported), in Pomeroon-Supenaam region, a mob looted and destroyed the shop of a businessman and assaulted an employee. The owner of the shop allegedly shot and killed a teen which angered the mob. [size=no report]

On 16 May 2020, in Georgetown, Demerara-Mahaica, supporters of PPP/C protested to demand the entry of election observers into the country. The observers from the Carter Center were supposed to observe the recount but were blocked from entering the country with coronavirus cited as a reason. The protesters were dispersed and one was arrested, supposedly because they were in violation of social distancing guidelines. [size=no report]
APNU-AFC: A Partnership for National Unity-Alliance for Change

On 9 May 2020, in Georgetown, Demerara-Mahaica, protesters shouted at a member of the 'Guardians of Democracy', a group that took the task of guarding ballot boxes. One woman was arrested. [size=no report]

On 5 May 2020, in Georgetown, Demerara-Mahaica, protesters picketed outside the President's residence against the decision not to let international observers into the country for the recount of the election ballots. [size=no report]
On 3 May 2020, in Whim, East Berbice-Corentyne, farmers protested in front of the branch office of the Environmental Protection Agency after water pollution destroyed their crops. [size=no report]
On 3 April 2020, througout Guyana, a curfew was imposed to prevent the spread of coronavirus.
On 27 March 2020, New Amsterdam and Linden, the second and third largest towns in Guyana imposed curfews to prevent the spread of coronavirus.
APNU-AFC: A Partnership for National Unity-Alliance for Change

In the week of 20 March 2020, in Georgetown Guyana, Election observers of the Carter Center reportedly suffered from harassment from demonstrators supportive of A Partnership for National Unity + Alliance For Change (APNU+AFC), who blocked them from doing their work. [size=no report]

On 16 March 2020, a group of police in full riot gear entered the convention center where the recount of the contested Guyanan elections were being held, and ordered representatives of several opposition parties to either leave the center or face arrest. At least one Opposition-appointed Commissioner was injured in the event.
APNU-AFC: A Partnership for National Unity-Alliance for Change

On 13 March 2020, in Georgetown, Demerara-Mahaica, a group of supporters of the APNU-AFC coalition attacked a number of journalists outside of the Guyana Elections Commission headquarters when the journalists attempted to enter the headquarters. [size=no report]
APNU-AFC: A Partnership for National Unity-Alliance for Change

On 15 March 2018, minibus drivers in Georgetown, Guyana, protested against the police for penalizing the drivers for marking their cars with multi-coloured wraps to indicate their routes.
On 14 March 2018, security guards protested outside of the Regional Democratic Council's (RDC) building in Fort Wellington, Guyana, to demand outstanding wages to be paid.
On 7 March 2018, stallholders selling their products inside the Bourda market, protested in Georgetown, Guyana, against street vendors selling their goods outside of the official market.

On 2 March 2018, in Georgetown, Demerara-Mahaica, a mob of people attacked a member of the joint services after an argument broke out between him and a drinks vendor. The argument started when the officer tried to prevent sellings in an unauthorized event.A police officer had to rescue the man from the mob. While they walked away the police officer was shot in the back by one of the people. No fatalities. [size=no report]
On 25 February 2018, security guards in New Amsterdam, Guyana, protested outside of their company's New Amsterdam office, as they demand the payment of outstanding wages.

On 21 February 2018, in Georgetown, Demerara-Mahaica, former Wales Estate sugar workers staged a demonstration outside the Ministry of Agriculture offices on Brickdam street to demand the minister to resign and their owed severance to be paid. [size=no report]
Around 15 February 2018 (month of), in New Amsterdam, East Berbice-Corentyne, security guards who are tasked with protecting government properties protested over unpaid salaries. [size=no report]
Labour Group (Guyana); GAWU: Guyana Agricultural and General Workers Union

On 12 February 2018, near Port Mourant, East Berbice-Corentyne, laid-off sugar workers and members of the GAWU union marched asking for the sugar estates to be reopened and for the payment of severance to those who were laid off. [size=no report]
On 6 February 2018, members of the Guyana Public Service Cooperative Credit Union, protested in front of their offices in Georgetown, Guyana, to demand dividend payment.
GAWU: Guyana Agricultural and General Workers Union; Labour Group (Guyana); Farmers (Guyana)

On 1 February 2018, former workers of Wales Sugar Estate (affiliated to GAWU: Guyana Agricultural and General Workers Union) protested in Georgetown, Guyana, to demand severance payments they are owed.

On 1 February 2018, Guyanese citizens protested outside the Venezuelan embassy in Georgetown, Guyana, to demand Guyanese sovereignty from the Venezuelan president and withdraw his unlawful claim to Essequibo.

On 30 January 2018, in Fort Wellington, Mahaica-Berbice, women who work as cleaners for the government protested because they say that their wages are unfair. The wages of some cleaners are higher than others, which protesters demanded be rectified. Also, they demanded to be given the benefit of maternity leave. [size=no report]
APNU-AFC: A Partnership for National Unity-Alliance for Change

Around 26 January 2018 (as reported), in New Amsterdam, East Berbice-Corentyne, supporters of ANPU-AFC picketed outside of an outreach meeting organized by their rival PPP party who were meeting with sugar workers who lost their jobs. Picketers shouted protests and threats at PPP members, though the protest remained peaceful. Police officers were present without intervening. [size=no report]

On 26 January 2018, in East Canje, East Berbice-Corentyne, hundreds of protesters including sugar workers protested during the visit of the Prime Minister. The workers had not received their severance pay. [size=hundreds]

On 26 January 2018, in Skeldon, East Berbice-Corentyne, hundreds of protesters including sugar workers protested during the visit of the Prime Minister. The workers had not received their severance pay. [size=hundreds]
On 24 January 2018, in Linden, Upper Takutu-Upper Essequibo, cleaners protested in front of the Regional Democratic Office for a pay increase and against poor working condition. [size=no report]
On 18 January 2018, in Linden, Upper Takutu-Upper Essequibo, more than two dozen cleaners protested for a pay increase and against poor working condition. [size=more than two dozen]
Around 15 January 2018 (month of), in New Amsterdam, East Berbice-Corentyne, security guards who are tasked with protecting government properties protested over unpaid salaries. [size=no report]

On 13 January 2018, in New Amsterdam, East Berbice-Corentyne, a group of members and followers of the Opposition Peoples Progressive Party (PPP) staged a demonstration in the sector when the President David Granger was coming to the city, to complain about the layoffs of sugar workers, high crime rate and unilateral appointment of a chairman. Police forces intervened and arrested some protesters. [size=no report]
On 13 January 2018, bus drivers protested in Georgetown, Guyana, against street vendors potentially coming to the park they are located.
On 11 January 2018, security guards in New Amsterdam, Guyana, protested outside of their company's New Amsterdam office, as they demand the payment of outstanding wages.

On 9 January 2018, near Port Mourant, East Berbice-Corentyne, scores of sugar workers who lost their jobs, accompanied by protesters against the government and family, protested to demand that they receive their severance pay which was promised. [size=scores]

On 4 January 2018, in Georgetown, Demerara-Mahaica, a few protesters picketed outside of the city hall to demand that the Mayor and City Council be dismissed and arrested. The protesters were angry after a staff member who was accused of rape was reinstated to the City Council. [size=no report]
